text: [Music]
hey everybody today's kitchen conundrum
is in response to some of the comments
that i've been receiving
pastry cream apparently it's a problem
for a lot of people whether it turns out
grainy or the instructions are
complicated
i found an easier way to make pastry
cream and it's so simple it's all in one
pot it's a dump and stir and it's making
it so much faster and even better let me
show you how in a small saucepan here
i'm going to add a half a cup of
granulated sugar
and a quarter of a cup of corn starch
here and i'm going to whisk these two
ingredients together right in the base
of the pot it sifts together the
cornstarch which tends to clump up with
the sugar so the sugar particles really
break up the corn starch and you won't
get any little lumps in your pastry
cream and pastry cream by the way is
that wonderful pudding-like filling
that's used in eclairs cream puffs
layered between um
puff pastry for napoleons and filled in
those wonderful berry tarts it really is
one of those great french
all-purpose fillings that's used in so
many different recipes so the corn
starch and the sugar are completely
sifted together i'm going to add a hefty
pinch of salt which is really important
when you're making sweets to add a
little bit of salt it brings out the
flavor
so that's the dry ingredients the wet
ingredients i have two cups of whole
milk i'm gonna add four egg yolks right
to the milk and now typically
here with pastry cream you would temper
in hot milk to the yolks and what
tempering means is bringing up the yolks
the temperature of the milk that's how
you would normally temper but we're
doing it in a whole new way so we have
room temperature milk and we have room
temperature egg yolks they could even be
cold and you really want to whisk them
together until they're nice and evenly
incorporated here
and i'm going to whisk while i add this
milk yolk mixture
into the cornstarch just want to make
sure that you're whisking as you pour so
that no lumps form
and now to this i'm going to add the
butter which is typically something that
you add in at the end of pastry cream
but i'm going to add it right from the
start so once this is all stirred
together
a medium heat
and you want the butter to melt and this
mixture will start to thicken and you
have to make sure that when you're
making pastry cream you actually have to
let it boil because cornstarch does not
fully activate unless it is brought to a
boil so the pudding is nice and thick
it's boiling you can see it's bubbling
up and you have to continue to do this
for a full minute make sure that you are
constantly whisking on this medium heat
so it's been about a minute i'm going to
add the flavoring now i'm using a really
good quality vanilla extract if you
wanted to make this a different flavor
you could absolutely maybe whisk in some
espresso powder if you wanted it to have
a coffee flavor
so now i'm going to strain it through a
fine mesh sieve and this really isn't
necessary at all you can totally skip
this step but what it does do is it just
pulls out any little egg particles that
you may have so just give it a little
bit of a stir in the sieve make sure you
get the bottom side of the sieve because
that's kind of where all of the pastry
cream hides out
cover the pastry cream with plastic wrap
and you want to make sure that you press
the plastic wrap directly on top of the
pastry cream this prevents the pastry
cream from forming a skin while it
chills so the pastry cream is out of the
fridge now like i said before you need
to chill this until it's nice and firm
and that takes about two hours but you
can do this up to two days in advance
it's really great i'm just gonna give
this a stir to kind of break up the
pastry cream a little bit and if you
really wanted a lighter pastry cream you
could fold in a little bit of whipped
cream here that would be fantastic as
well
i'm gonna go right into a nine inch
blind baked tart shell and using an
offset spatula that's what this thing is
called it's an offset spatula because
the handle is raised
just push the pastry cream out to the
edges
you don't have to be fancy here
and then one of my favorite things to do
is just to garnish the top with
raspberries and you could be
you could be really picky and finicky
and you can arrange them like little
soldiers all around but i just like to
be a little bit more organic here and i
just kind of toss them around the top
and they might sink into the filling a
little bit but you can get this right
into the refrigerator chill it till it's
nice and firm and it will slice
beautifully
what i like to do is just give it a
light dusting of confectioners sugar
right over the raspberries and you have
a simple
yet elegant dessert with your no fuss
one pot curdle-free pastry cream
if you have any kitchen conundrums that
you need solved write in the comments
section below or reach out to me using
the hashtag kitchenconundrums and i will
solve whatever kitchen problems you may
have
you
